text: Happy New Year everyone! I have a question about a content marketing trend. What's one thing you don't like about long-form content? It could be anything; from writing it to editing it to reading it.

elements.text: Happy New Year everyone! I have a question about a content marketing trend. What's one thing you don't like about long-form content? It could be anything; from writing it to editing it to reading it.

text: You could add it, see if people use it with a heatmap/click tracking? Personally I like TOCs, and also like that the links can show up in the serps to help increase CTR

elements.text: You could add it, see if people use it with a heatmap/click tracking? Personally I like TOCs, and also like that the links can show up in the serps to help increase CTR

text: For me the worst thing is when people/clients want (or think they want) long form content for SEO or other purposes, but don't actually have that much of substance to say.

elements.text: For me the worst thing is when people/clients want (or think they want) long form content for SEO or other purposes, but don't actually have that much of substance to say.

text: Writing it for sure. :sleepy:

elements.text: Writing it for sure.

text:
I often read business books and think to myself “Could this have been a blog post? yes”. At which point I start skipping pages and mostly looking at headings.

Same with long-form content: if it’s long form not because the author legitimately had something to say, but because they were just trying to hit an arbitrary word count and make it ‘long’, I will abandon it fairly quickly.

text: Lots of folks *think* they need to write long-form content because that’s what they read on the Backlinko blog. But that’s an incorrect take-away.

elements.text: Lots of folks
think
they need to write long-form content because that’s what they read on the Backlinko blog. But that’s an incorrect take-away.

text: I don’t like when it replicates what everyone else has said on the topic.  As Dave says, often people go for long form for SEO purposes. Many writers (who have SEO in mind) also think they need to build a post that looks like every other post on page one. Far better to add a richness and depth to what’s already out there with an alternative perspective or with original quantitative and qualitative research (as John Bonini recommends). I hope we evolve past reimagined, single POV, long-form posts.

elements.text: I don’t like when it replicates what everyone else has said on the topic.  As Dave says, often people go for long form for SEO purposes. Many writers (who have SEO in mind) also think they need to build a post that looks like every other post on page one. Far better to add a richness and depth to what’s already out there with an alternative perspective or with original quantitative and qualitative research (as John Bonini recommends). I hope we evolve past reimagined, single POV, long-form posts.

text: The very best long form content I've read over the years has a clear "story." I don't mean "story" in a fictional sense, but rather that the pieces have structure that takes the reader from point A to point B to point C, much like a narrative. The good long form pieces also have content that I haven't seen in other locations (data analysis, trends analysis, a behind-the-scenes view of something/someone/some place). As a result, long form articles that don't have these two qualities (story and original insight) always feel like a word dump to me.

elements.text: The very best long form content I've read over the years has a clear "story." As a result, long form articles that don't have these two qualities (story and original insight) always feel like a word dump to me.

text:
Hi all, former content marketer here, turned founder (<http://teamgather.co|teamgather.co>), now building out our startup's content marketing program. We have a concept we want to test out which includes hiring our target audience to write blog pieces for us. Here's what we're thinking:

`We want to contract Heads of People Operations (our target customer) to write posts about the people operations programs they're building at their own companies. Many of these folks are good writers and know the blog post format well, but we expect a mixed bag with a lot of editing on our end. Plus they are busy FT workers. I have a budget of $10K over the next 9 months to test this out, make the most of it, and find out if this is going to be worthwhile for us.`

Questions for you:
• How would you go about allocating the money and setting rates for these folks?
• How would you formalize some of these processes here so this doesn't become too chaotic? (just looking to avoid common pitfalls really)
Thanks in advance for the help! Love this community.

elements.text: Hi all, former content marketer here, turned founder (
teamgather.co
), now building out our startup's content marketing program. We have a concept we want to test out which includes hiring our target audience to write blog pieces for us. Here's what we're thinking:

We want to contract Heads of People Operations (our target customer) to write posts about the people operations programs they're building at their own companies. Many of these folks are good writers and know the blog post format well, but we expect a mixed bag with a lot of editing on our end. Plus they are busy FT workers. I have a budget of $10K over the next 9 months to test this out, make the most of it, and find out if this is going to be worthwhile for us.
Questions for you:
How would you go about allocating the money and setting rates for these folks?
How would you formalize some of these processes here so this doesn't become too chaotic? (just looking to avoid common pitfalls really)
Thanks in advance for the help! Love this community.

text: Hey <@UJG5B682Y>, I know it’s not exactly what you asked but: is there a scenario where you get some freelance writers to interview the Heads and ghostwrite on their behalf? This might be a faster way to create content + avoid too many editorial rounds

elements.text: Hey

text: <@U017WRJTKF1> In the long run, yes I think that makes a lot of sense. In the next 9 months, probably not, given the budget space for this experiment. In my mind, I'm targeting 15-20 posts out of this in the next 9 months and in my head, the math doesn't work to get another editor involved besides me.

text: That’s what I used to do in my previous job, though. I’d do the interviews, then hand over the raw transcript to the freelancer. Which also leads to another possible suggestion: if you have time, YOU do the interviews, the freelancers do the writing :wink:

text:
<@U017WRJTKF1> Yes, it is. In my opinion, what people are doing with long form content is what they've done with every other marketing trend. 

Jump on it because everyone else is getting on. They don't think about what their readers really need or if it fits into their marketing strategy. 

In the end, content is produced but not utilized by the audience. Just as you said people abandon blog posts quickly. 

:persevere: just thinking about the wasted effort/time makes me shudder.

elements.text:

In the end, content is produced but not utilized by the audience. Just as you said people abandon blog posts quickly.
just thinking about the wasted effort/time makes me shudder.

text:
I agree! Most SERPs look like copies of each other. Animalz has a post on this topic. 

:thinking_face: there are writers that can't do much because the SEO brief demands they follow a certain format. And then there are writers who don't dig in deep and lack the motivation to do better. 

At the receiving end is the reader who has to sift through tons of empty words to find answers. 

I

text:
<@U01BLESEU1E> your perspective is really interesting. 

I think I've read pieces like that. They had a velvety flow and I transitioned from idea to idea easily. Those are simply a delight to read. 

Oh, I read one now not long ago. It's on Elon Musk's Neuralink. The author dove deep into the structure of the brain and all that. And there I was (a person who detested biology in school) reading and reading. 

The way he explained concepts was captivating and he used stories and scenarios I could relate to. And he led me from one idea to another with his words. 

If just long form writers could have just a small bit of the author's magic, I am sure such posts would not be dreadful anymore.

text:
Another option to avoid having the target need to write out something (some people truly, TRULY struggle to compose thoughts in writing, and the experience may be terrible for them even if they're paid decently to do it) is to send them a solid form.

The form can be comprehensive and mostly allow for long form, open ended answers. BUT you can also slip in some quantitative bits too, and use the aggregate  or individual data as further supplementary content.

You then send the responses to an expert writer and/or editor team who's been briefed on your brand and can content-ify the form responses.

It's essentially the interview approach suggested here with the interview part swapped for a good survey. That might save some $ in production and get you some interesting data as well :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

text:
Hey everyone!
Optimising blogs for the New Year is an obvious tactic that picks up this time of the year.
My #SEO question is whether the approach is just updating the headline i.e *best of X 2020* to *best of X 2021* or do you folks go deeper?

If deep, how deep? What are the things that you update and whether it means updating the publish date as well. Is that in any way necessary? I'll appreciate help on this one!
